title: What are the similarities of humanities and natural science? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ll riff on this — The Humanities use Natural Science as an inescapable foundation. This is summarized in one pithy statement by Aristotle: “Art is an imitation of Life.” The Humanities (i.e. Aesthetics, Ethics, Economics, Politics, Rhetoric, Poetry, Music, Literature, Fine and Performing Arts, Theater, Art Criticism, History) presume the existence of Humanity. Humanity — as Aristotle showed — is inevitably bound up with Nature and the four main drives of life: (1) to eat; (2) to sleep; (3) to procreate; and (4) to defend. These must be fulfilled before the community can exist — and the community must exist before the Humanities can develop. There was a hunting tribe with a chief before there was cave painting. Now — what about Science Fiction, Fantasy, and so forth, which are Anti-Natural? Aristotle’s observation remains true — because there is such a thing as Negative Imitation. Just doing the Opposite of what one observes others doing. This is no more creative than the brilliant imitation of Life that we see in Shakespeare for example. Again — Nature exists first, in all its complexity. Then Humanity appears. Then the many Arts of the Humanities appear. That’s the Order. Somebody must know how to make paint, before there can be painting. Somebody must know how strings, reeds, wood and brass vibrate, before there can be music. But, doesn’t Religion transcend Nature? No — Religion only goes to the Source of Nature — the Creator — with recognition, gratitude, ritual and meditation. In most forms it doesn’t abandon Nature. (“For God so loved the World…” Some forms of Religion like Gnosticism, Monasticism, etc. do try to “leave the body” and “deny the senses” but that was always an unending struggle — more of a dream than a genuine attainment.) Anyway — the Humanities all presume that some Natural Science must exist first, in some form or other. There’s my riff.
